sections.content:
## warm-up

In English, you always need a verb. You say: "I **am** a student." You cannot just say "I student." It sounds like Tarzan.
In Ukrainian, you say exactly that: "I student." (**–Ø —Å—Ç—É–¥–µ–Ω—Ç**).

In English: "This **is** a bank."
In Ukrainian: "This bank." (**–¶–µ –±–∞–Ω–∫**).

Welcome to the **Zero Copula**. This sounds like a complex sci-fi term, but it simply means "No Verb Needed". Ukrainian is efficient. In the present tense, the verb "to be" (am, is, are) usually disappears! It exists in the past ("was") and future ("will be"), but right now, it is invisible.
This makes speaking Ukrainian surprisingly fast and direct. You just put two words together‚ÄîSubject and Noun‚Äîand boom, you have a perfect sentence.

> üí° **Did You Know?**
>
> This "Zero Copula" feature is common in many languages, including Russian, Arabic, and Hebrew. It implies that being is the default state of existence. You don't need to *assert* that you "ARE" a student; simply stating "I Student" implies existence.
>
> However, there IS a word for "is" (**—î**), but it is used only for emphatic definitions or philosophical statements (e.g., "God is Love" - *–ë–æ–≥ —î –õ—é–±–æ–≤*). Or in formal definitions: "Kyiv is the capital of Ukraine" (*–ö–∏—ó–≤ —î —Å—Ç–æ–ª–∏—Ü–µ—é –£–∫—Ä–∞—ó–Ω–∏*). But for everyday speech? Skip it!
> *"–Ø —Å—Ç—É–¥–µ–Ω—Ç"* is natural. *"–Ø —î —Å—Ç—É–¥–µ–Ω—Ç"* sounds like a robot or a philosopher trying to prove their existence.

## presentation

### 1. Subject Pronouns (The Actors)

First, we need to know *who* is speaking. The pronouns are your avatars in the game of language.

| English | Ukrainian | Pronunciation | Note |
|---------|-----------|---------------|------|
| **I** | **–Ø** | /ja/ | Sounds like "Ya" in "Yard". |
| **You** (informal) | **–¢–∏** | /t…™/ | "Ty" (Like 'sit' but deeper). |
| **He** | **–í—ñ–Ω** | /vin/ | "Vin" (Diesel). |
| **She** | **–í–æ–Ω–∞** | /v…îÀàn…ë/ | "Vo-na" (Rhymes with 'Donna'). |
| **It** | **–í–æ–Ω–æ** | /v…îÀàn…î/ | "Vo-no". |
| **We** | **–ú–∏** | /m…™/ | "My" (Like 'myth'). |
| **You** (formal/plural) | **–í–∏** | /v…™/ | "Vy" (Like 'visit'). |
| **They** | **–í–æ–Ω–∏** | /v…îÀàn…™/ | "Vo-ny". |

> ‚ö° **Pro Tip: The Art of Politeness (Ty vs Vy)**
>
> The distinction between **–¢–∏** (You-Singular) and **–í–∏** (You-Plural/Formal) is critical in Ukrainian society. It is not just grammar; it is social hierarchy.
> - Use **–¢–∏** with friends, children, family members, pets, and God (in prayer).
> - Use **–í–∏** with strangers, elders, teachers, officials, and ANY group of people (even two children).
>
> **The Danger Zone:**
> If you call your boss "–¢–∏", you might get fired (or at least a stern look). If you call a young child "–í–∏", they will giggle because you sound too serious.
> In Ukrainian culture, switching from "–í–∏" to "–¢–∏" is a major milestone in a relationship. It usually happens after a shared experience, a drink, or simply asking: *"Can we switch to Ty?"* (*–ú–æ–∂–µ, –ø–µ—Ä–µ–π–¥–µ–º–æ –Ω–∞ —Ç–∏?*). Until that moment, keep your "Vy" shield up!

### 2. The Magic Word: –¶–µ (Tse)

**–¶–µ** means "This gets" or "It is". It is your universal pointing word. It never changes. It doesn't care about gender. It is the finger you point with.
- **–¶–µ** –±–∞–Ω–∫. (This is a bank).
- **–¶–µ** –º–∞–º–∞. (This is mom).
- **–¶–µ** –Ω–µ –ø–∞—Ä–∫. (This is not a park).

To make a question, just change your intonation! Raise your voice at the end like you are asking a favor.
- **–¶–µ** –ø–∞—Ä–∫. (Statement: This is a park.) ‚Üò
- **–¶–µ** –ø–∞—Ä–∫? (Question: Is this a park?) ‚Üó

### 3. Sentence Building (Subject + Predicate)

Since we don't need "is/am/are", we just stick the pronoun and the noun together. This is the lego-block method of language learning.

- I (am a) student. = **–Ø —Å—Ç—É–¥–µ–Ω—Ç.**
- He (is a) doctor. = **–í—ñ–Ω –¥–æ–∫—Ç–æ—Ä.**
- We (are) tourists. = **–ú–∏ —Ç—É—Ä–∏—Å—Ç–∏.**
- They (are) actors. = **–í–æ–Ω–∏ –∞–∫—Ç–æ—Ä–∏.**

> üîç **Deep Dive: The Feminitive Revolution**
>
> You might notice that "Student" is **–°—Ç—É–¥–µ–Ω—Ç**, but a female student is **–°—Ç—É–¥–µ–Ω—Ç–∫–∞**.
> In the Soviet era, official titles were often masculine-only ("Doctor", "Director", "Engineer"). But historically, Ukrainian has always had rich feminine forms for professions.
> Today, Ukraine is experiencing a "Feminitive Boom". Using words like **–î–∏—Ä–µ–∫—Ç–æ—Ä–∫–∞** (female director), **–§–æ—Ç–æ–≥—Ä–∞—Ñ–∏–Ω—è** (female photographer), and **IT-—à–Ω–∏—Ü—è** (female IT specialist) is a way to make women visible in the language.
> While our vocabulary list gives the base forms (usually masculine), know that for almost every profession, there is a dedicated female counterpart waiting to be used!

## practice

Let's practice the "Zero Copula". Translate literally in your head: "She actor".

1. **–í–æ–Ω–∞ –∞–∫—Ç—Ä–∏—Å–∞.** (She is an actress).
2. **–¢–∏ —Å—Ç—É–¥–µ–Ω—Ç.** (You are a student).
3. **–ú–∏ —Ç—É—Ç.** (We are here).
4. **–í–∏ —Ç–∞–º.** (You are there).

**Negation**
To say "not", use **–Ω–µ**. Put it before the word you want to negate.
- **–Ø –Ω–µ —Å—Ç—É–¥–µ–Ω—Ç.** (I am not a student).
- **–¶–µ –Ω–µ –±–∞–Ω–∫.** (This is not a bank).

> üé≠ **Culture Corner**
>
> Ukrainians value titles and professions. When asking "Hto tse?" (Who is this?), the answer often defines the person by their role. "Vatse likar" (That is a doctor).
>
> **Conversation Etiquette:**
> When you meet someone for the first time, the script is simple but strict:
> 1. **–ü—Ä–∏–≤—ñ—Ç!** (Hi - Casual) OR **–î–æ–±—Ä–∏–π –¥–µ–Ω—å!** (Good day - Formal).
> 2. **–Ø–∫ —Å–ø—Ä–∞–≤–∏?** (How are things?). unlike in the US, "How are things?" is a real question. You can say "Normal" (*–ù–æ—Ä–º–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ*), but don't just say "Great" if your house is on fire. Ukrainians value honesty (within reason).
> 3. **–Ø–∫ –≤–∞—Å –∑–≤–∞—Ç–∏?** (What is your name? Lit: How [do they] call you?).
> 4. **–ú–µ–Ω–µ –∑–≤–∞—Ç–∏...** (My name is... Lit: Me [they] call...).
>
> Notice the passive construction "Me they call". It implies your name is something given to you by the world. It is less ego-centric than "I AM [Name]".

## production

Look at people around you (or imagine them).
1. Point to yourself: **–Ø —Ç—É—Ä–∏—Å—Ç.** (I am a tourist).
2. Point to a friend: **–¢–∏ –¥—Ä—É–≥.** (You are a friend).
3. Point to a group: **–í–æ–Ω–∏ —Å—Ç—É–¥–µ–Ω—Ç–∏.** (They are students).

Ask questions:
- **–•—Ç–æ —Ü–µ?** (Who is this?) -> **–¶–µ –º–∞–º–∞.**
- **–©–æ —Ü–µ?** (What is this?) -> **–¶–µ —Ç–µ–ª–µ—Ñ–æ–Ω.**

Think like a Ukrainian. Remove the "is". Be direct. "This - Bank". "I - Tourist". Efficient, strong, simple.

sections.content: > You are now a sentence-builder. You can define the world: "This is X, this is Y." You can introduce yourself and others: "I am X, he is Y." You know the "Zero Copula" secret, which allows you to bypass complex verb conjugations for now. You also know that politeness matters ("Ty" vs "Vy"), and that almost every profession has a female form waiting to be used. In the next module, we will expand your world to "My World"‚Äîlearning to say "My book," "Your coffee," and owning the things around you.

# Summary

> You are now a sentence-builder. You can define the world: "This is X, this is Y." You can introduce yourself and others: "I am X, he is Y." You know the "Zero Copula" secret, which allows you to bypass complex verb conjugations for now. You also know that politeness matters ("Ty" vs "Vy"), and that almost every profession has a female form waiting to be used. In the next module, we will expand your world to "My World"‚Äîlearning to say "My book," "Your coffee," and owning the things around you.
